required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Massage on Post-exercise Recovery on Functional Performance
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Massage on Post-exercise Recovery on Functional, Clinical and Metabolic Outcomes

brief_summary.textblock:
Introduction: Post-exercise recovery techniques have been extensively investigated in order to optimize the restoration of various body functions and consequently of performance. Massage represents approximately 45% of the time spent by a sports physiotherapist in the field, however, their mechanisms are not well established and studies present divergent results in the literature.
Objectives: The objective of this study is to analyze and compare the effects of massage when applied immediately or 1 hour after physical exertion, on functional, clinical and metabolic variables.
Design: A cross-over randomized clinical trial.
Participants: Forty men aged 18 to 30 years, healthy and that fulfilling the eligibility criteria.
Procedures: Participants will be randomized into five groups (n = 8 per group): (GA, GB, GC, GD and GE), which will perform the 5 stages of the study at randomized times, one stage per session. Stage 1: control; Stage 2: Participants will receive the massage protocol; Stage 3: physical exercise protocol; Stage 4: Participants will perform the physical exercise protocol and immediately after, will receive the massage; Stage 5: Participants will perform the physical exercise protocol and 1 hour after the end of the exercise they will receive the massage. Sessions will occur with a 1-week interval between them.
Measurements. The primary outcome measures will be measured 2h after the start of each stage, and the secondary outcome measures will be measured at specific times during each stage. The primary outcome includes measures of functional performance, and the measures of secondary outcome includes clinical and metabolic variables.

detailed_description.textblock:
Introduction: Post-exercise recovery techniques have been extensively investigated in order to optimize the restoration of various body functions and consequently of performance. Massage represents approximately 45% of the time spent by a sports physiotherapist in the field, however, their mechanisms are not well established and studies present divergent results in the literature.
Objectives: The objective of this study is to analyze the magnitude of the effects of massage on functional, clinical and metabolic variables. The secondary objective is to compare the effect of manual massage as a post-exercise recovery technique applied at different times (1. Immediately after physical exertion; 2. 1 hour after the end of intense exercise) on the functional, clinical and metabolic outcomes of physically active subjects
Design: A cross-over randomized clinical trial.
Participants: After fulfilling the eligibility criteria, forty male participants will participate in the study. The inclusion criteria include: healthy male, aged between 18-30 years, with level of physical activity within the group average. The exclusion criteria include: presence of anemia, inflammatory process, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, alcoholics, smokers, users of illicit drugs, chronic users of anti-inflammatory drugs and occurrence of muscle injuries in the lower limbs and/or trunk in the last six months.
Procedures: Participants will be randomized into five groups (n = 8 per group): (GA, GB, GC, GD and GE), which will perform the 5 stages of the study at randomized times, one stage per session. Stage 1: control; Stage 2: Participants will receive the massage protocol; Stage 3: physical exercise protocol; Stage 4: Participants will perform the physical exercise protocol and immediately after, will receive the massage; Stage 5: Participants will perform the physical exercise protocol and 1 hour after the end of the exercise they will receive the massage. Sessions will occur with a 1-week interval between them.
Intervention: The first three stages of the study (E1, E2 and E3) will be performed to know the basal behavior of the study variables and / or before the two different stimuli (massage and physical exercise). In stages 4 and 5 will be performed the analysis of the effects of massage on post-exercise recovery, and the comparison of the effects of massage when performed immediately after exertion or 1 hour after exertion. The sequence of performance of the functional tests will always be the same, regardless of the stage of the study, being the following order: 1st Vertical Jump Test; 2º Maximum Isometric Voluntary
Measurements. The primary outcome measures will be measured 2h after the start of each stage, and the secondary outcome measures will be measured at specific times during each stage. The primary measures includes the Strength and power test, Maximal voluntary isometric contraction (MVIC) and Squat jump. The secondary measures includes the subjective pain assessment, perception of recovery, psychological questionnaire, belief questionnaire and de analysis blood lactate concentration.
Analysis: The normality of the data will be evaluated through the Shapiro-Wilk test. For the analysis of the clinical, functional and metabolic parameters between the groups in the case of normal distribution, one-way ANOVA with post-test of Tukey and Kruskal-Wallis will be adopted with Dunn post-test if there is no normal distribution. For the analysis of these parameters, however, within the groups (moments of analysis) will be used ANOVA for repeated measurements with Tukey post-test for normal data and Friedman's test with Dunn post-test for non-normal data. The level of significance was set at p <0.05 for all tests.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; and 2h after the stress protocol.
primary_outcome.description: The participant will make a jump keeping the knees extended (180º of angulation) and back until touching the platform again. He will start by the position with the soles of the feet in contact with the heel platform (Multisprint, Hidrofit, Brazil), hands at the waist, erect trunk and lower limbs flexed at 90º. Three complete tests with a 30-second rest interval will be performed between each repetition. The best measurement of jump height will be adopted.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: In Stage 1 (Baseline), Immediately 2h after the initiation of the massage protocol in Stage 2, and Immediately 2h after the initiation of the stress protocol in Stages 3, 4 and 5.
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will be positioned with the dominant leg on the isokinetic dynamometer (Biodex System 4 Pro, New York, USA). As suggested in the protocol by Baroni et al., 201015, prior to the MVIC evaluation, participants will conduct a warm up consisting of 10 repetitions of knee flexion-extension at 180°.s-1 throughout the range of motion. The MVIC will be determined by the highest maximal isometric torque over three contractions of five seconds at 60° of knee flexion (with 0° corresponding to the maximum extension). The repetitions will be separated by a 2-minute rest interval. Participants will be instructed to perform maximal contractions and verbally encouraged by the researcher during the evaluation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: In Stage 1 (Baseline), Immediately 2h after the initiation of the massage protocol in Stage 2, and Immediately 2h after the initiation of the stress protocol in Stages 3, 4 and 5.
secondary_outcome.description: With a vertical squat with a guided bar the strength and power tests will be performed. The participant should perform a squatting in continuous motion until the legs reach the 90° angle, and then perform the opposite movement, returning to the upright position. Participants will wear a protective belt. The distance taken eccentrically and the concentric velocity of each repetition will be recorded by means of a linear velocity transducer (T-Force System, Ergotech, Murcia, Spain). The mean velocity of the eccentric phase will be controlled (approximately 0,5 m/s) and in the concentric phase the velocity will be maximum.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: In Stage 1 (Baseline), Immediately before the initiation of the massage protocol in Stage 2, and Immediately before the initiation of the stress protocol in Stages 3, 4 and 5.
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will complete a psychological questionnaire that aims to document, subjectively, the readiness for exercise, fatigue, vigor, sleepiness, and pain. Participants will be instructed to mark an "X" on a 10-cm visual analog scale between two extremes, with 'zero' corresponding to 'least possible' and '10' 'most possible' for each rating.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately before the initiation of the stress protocol in Stages 4 and 5.
secondary_outcome.description: It is a questionnaire designed to measure a belief about an effectiveness of the technique that is exposed. Participants were instructed to respond with "Yes", "No" or "Do not Know" the following question: "Do you have a massage will be beneficial to your muscle recovery after intense exercise?".

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Will be collected prior to the initiation of the stress protocol, and at minutes 2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 30, 45, 60, 75, 90, 105 and 120 after the stress protocol.
secondary_outcome.description: The blood lactate concentration will be collected in heparinized capillaries, 25 μl of ear lobe arterialized blood, and discarded in eppendorff (1.5 mL) polyethylene tubes containing 50 μl of sodium fluoride (NaF - 1% ), For later lactacidemic analysis, performed in a lactimeter (YSI, Yellow Springs - 1500). The lactate values will be expressed in mmol / L.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: In Stages 4 and 5: immediately after and in the minutes 13, 60, 72 and 120 after the stress protocol.
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will be questioned about the presence of pain in the lower limbs at the moment, by means of the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), graduated from 0 to 10, being zero the total absence of pain and 10 the maximum level of pain supported by the individual.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: In Stages 4 and 5: immediately after and in the minutes 13, 60, 72 and 120 after the stress protocol.
secondary_outcome.description: Perception of recovery will be assessed by a 10-point Likert Scale, with 'one' corresponding to 'not recovered' and '10' to 'fully recovery'.

arm_group.description: The behavior of the variables of functional and clinical outcome will be analyzed under no stress or recovery technique. In this stage, only the functional tests and the collection of clinical data will be performed.

The behavior of the variables of functional and clinical outcome will be analyzed under stress or recovery technique. In this stage, only the functional tests and the collection of clinical data will be performed.

The behavior of the variables of functional, clinical and metabolic outcome will be analyzed before the exercise protocol is performed. In this stage the volunteers will first perform the protocol for exhaustion, and in specific moments the blood lactate and clinical data will be collected, and 2h after the beginning of the exercise protocol, the functional tests will be performed.

In this stage, the behavior of the variables of functional, clinical and metabolic outcome will be analyzed from the exercise protocol, followed by massage. Firstly the volunteers will carry out the protocol for exhaustion and the massage application will be done immediately after the end of the exercise. Blood lactate and clinical data will be collected at specific times during this stage. After 2h of the beginning of the stress protocol, the functional tests will be performed.

In this stage, the behavior of the variables of functional, clinical and metabolic outcome will be analyzed before the exhaustion protocol and the application of the massage after 1h of passive recovery. Firstly the volunteers will perform the protocol for exercise, followed by a passive recovery of 1h and then the massage application. The functional tests will be performed 2 hours after the stress protocol begins. Again, blood lactate collection and clinical data will occur at specific times.

intervention.description: Participants will be submitted to an exercise protocol consisting of a jumping program and a maximum short cycle test (ALMEIDAetal). The jumping program consists of 10 sets of 10 jumps with one minute interval between sets. The participants will then perform the Wingate Anaerobic Test protocol, which will be performed on a Biotec 2100 cycle ergometer (Cefise, Nova Odessa, Brazil). A 5-minute warm-up will be carried out where the participant will pedal at a speed of 60 to 90 rpm with a fixed load of 1.0 kg and perform sprints in the 2nd and 4th minute and the test itself, which consists of a maximum of pedals In 30 seconds with a stipulated load of 0.075 kP · kg-1 of the participant's body mass.

the present protocol will have a total of 12 minutes duration, being six minutes in the anterior region of the thigh (three minutes for each limb) and six minutes in the posterior region of the trunk. Surface and deep sliding techniques will be used, the latter being presented in two intensities, moderate or intense, gradually increased. The massage will be performed towards the muscle fibers, from distal to proximal and following the lymphatic flow. In addition to the standardization of the intensity of the massage performed by the physiotherapist, in order to avoid causing discomfort and possible variations in the application of the technique, participants should report their level of comfort from a scale that considers the technique "light", "moderate" or "Intense", corresponding respectively to surface slip, Deep Slip 1 and Deep Slip 2.
